cards.html:
Hello {first_name, "there"},

The summer is finally here, in the northern hemisphere at least. I'm going to take advantage of the quieter period to try something a little bit different with OM&HB between now and September. Rather than always writing long pieces, and then sending them as newsletters, I'm going to get back into the old fashioned blog groove of writing shorter links posts to interesting news, and then summarise those posts in weekly newsletters to you.

After all, nobody wants to find a whole pile of unread emails building up in their inbox after a break, do they?

I'll reassess at the end of August (or sooner if my open rate plummetsâ€¦), but do let me know if this revised approach works for you.

cards.caption: I finally got to experience the resurrected Eurostar terminal at Waterloo last week, now converted to serve local lines. What a lovely space this has always been. It's great to see it in use again.
cards.alt: The old Eurostar terminal at London Waterloo, now back in use for local trains.

sections: It was inevitable. Facebook is starting to wind down some of its newer initiatives for journalism (and some of its old ones are pretty much dead already. Whan did you last hear about Instant Articles?) That means you need to start rethinking your strategy for Meta's platforms:

Digital societies are suffering from an experiential glut. We can experience more places and activities vicariously than ever before. What's the future of experiential journalism in the midst of this?
Instagram just ain't what it used to be, folks. If you still think it's for photo sharing, then you need to move with the times, and get with the hepcats, daddy-o.
